fields.summary: Extra rules to determine the next version number for deployments

fields.description:
In some locations, i.e. atlassian, deploy tasks can run from some (but not all) of our agents. These agents are also available for running normal jobs.

Being familiar with requirements and capabilities, I want to set a requirement to limit the agents the deploy can run on. I don't want to specify a bunch of agent names, cause they change all the time as agents are added and decommissioned.
fields.summary: Deployments need way to specify a shared pool of agents

fields.description:
It'd be nice to have Bamboo send a private message via hipchat to the owner/last committer of a feature branch to inform them that the build has passed or failed.

We recently enabled auto feature branch builds in the ecosystem team and the amount of statuses appearing in our channel is a bit annoying.
fields.summary: I want to personally know via hipchat when my feature branch fails or passes.

fields.description:
More important for deployments.

If you don't have any tasks in the build, then technically it can't do anything.  This should not be counted as a failure against an environment, cause technically the environment is still happily running the previous version.

The state should instead be NOT_BUILT.
fields.summary: If execution of deployment or build is prevented due to no tasks being defined, state should be NOT BUILT

fields.description:
Should allow shortcuts/aliases for most common use-cases:
- previous version
- most recently deployed version (per environment)
- ???
fields.summary: Enhance version picker on release comparison and preview pages

fields.description: or remove the distinction between artifacts and shared artifacts.
fields.summary: Artifacts should be shared by default

fields.description: Deployment project & environment configuration changes should be logged to the audit log.
fields.summary: Deployment project & environment configuration changes should show up in audit log

fields.description:
* On the initial build, we should show the latest commit (the commit on tip).
* If a release is created off the initial build, the version should contain exactly one commit (and issue info if there was a JIRA issue associated with the commit).
fields.summary: First deployment release has no commit/issue information.

fields.description: Disabling a deployment project or environment will disable any triggers and prevent any releases from being manually deployed.
fields.summary: Enable or disable a deployment project and environment

fields.description:
Because of the way CI bundles up commits, its possible a single commit may be in a passing build, but technically could be failing. (The fixing commit also being included in that build).  That means you may not want to deploy it unless you know 100% that its green.

Therefore we should indicate whether the releases commit is the last commit in the result, or just somewhere in the middle.
fields.summary: Release "Tested in" should indicate if it was last commit or middle commit.
Undeploy Tomcat tasks should allow for failure to be ignored

fields.description: I noticed that on the Bamboo Instance, the Marketplace is not fully searchable. You can't find all the plugins that exist on that Insall Page. However, going to marketplace.atlassian.com gives you everything, however you must either download the JAR or copy the link and use that.
fields.summary: Better Marketplace Browser

fields.description:
*Problem:*

Bamboo Clover Plugin allows to automatically integrate Clover with a Grails project. It uses a standard 'grails install-plugin' command to add Clover Grails Plugin to the project. This method is deprecated, however, as since Grails 1.3 it's possible to install plugin via dependency declaration in BuildConfig.groovy file.

Thus, for Clover-enabled projects a following warning is present in a log file:

{quote}
Warning The install-plugin command is deprecated and may be removed from a future version of Grails.  Plugin dependencies should be expressed in grails-app/conf/BuildConfig.groovy.  See http://grails.org/doc/2.2.x/guide/conf.html#pluginDependencies. 
{quote}

*Possible solution:*

Instead of 'grails install-plugin' modify content of the BuildConfig.groovy file on the fly and add 'clover' plugin dependency.

*Traps:* :-)
 
 * grails 1.2.x and older versions do not support this new way
 * you're modifying the original source ... keep a copy of original file?

It has a low priority as 'install-plugin' is still supported but just deprecated.
fields.summary: Use BuildConfig's DSL to install Clover plugin

fields.description:
From a conversation with Penny Wyatt:
it would be very helpful for checks before releases to call out open and in progress JIRA issues that are part of these releases, because there would usually be something wrong with the release, either in code or in JIRA.
fields.summary: Flag releases containing 'open' or 'in progress' JIRA issues

fields.description:
*Premisses:*
* Bamboo 4.4.5
* Git repository being checked out
* Git committer alias associated with a Bamboo User

*Steps to reproduce:*
* Create a new plan
* Make it checkout from a Git repository branch, it can be the {{master}} branch.
* Add a second task that will make the build fail (e.g., I added a JUnit Parser task, but I don't have any JUnit test results to parse, so it will fail).
* Don't enable the plan yet - you need to configure notifications first - but you can click on the {{Create}} button.
* After creating the plan, go to the Notifications tab, and configure the plan to send a notification for the event {{Failed Builds And First Successful}}, having {{Committers - Users who have committed to the build}} as Recipient Type.
* Click on the Action cog icon and enable the plan
* Run the plan manually.
* It will fail as expected, but no notifications arrive at the committer inbox.
* Remove the failing task (the JUnit Parser, in my case), and run the plan again.
* It will succeed, but no notifications arrive at the committer inbox either.

The exact same steps work if I choose to checkout from a SVN repository (i.e., the committer receives a notification), so the problem seems to be conditioned to when using Git as repository type.

No errors are written in the log files.
fields.summary: Problem with Failed Builds And First Successful notification when first build fails
Create a separate REST API service for Bamboo plan branches

fields.description:
h4. Issue Description
There will be Internal Server error whenever users try to view Task's details on the Job Configuration. The tasks list will be displayed, however upon clicking on each task, Internal Server Error will be returned. It might be related to BAM-5838. The following appears in the {{atlassian-bamboo.log}}:
{noformat}
ERROR [qtp850442967-124] [FiveOhOh] 500 Exception was thrown.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Neither input() nor doİnput() is found in action class com.atlassian.bamboo.ww2.actions.build.admin.config.task.EditTask
	at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invokeAction(DefaultActionInvocation.java:360)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invokeActionOnly(DefaultActionInvocation.java:218)
	at com.opensymphony.xwork.DefaultActionInvocation.invoke(DefaultActionInvocation.java:192)
	...
{noformat}

h4. Steps to replicate
*_If the server is using turkish locale skip to step number 2_*
# Edit the {{wrapper.conf}} in {{$BAMBOO-INSTALL/conf}} directory and append the following.
{noformat}
-Duser.country=TR
-Duser.language=tr
{noformat}
# Navigate to _Plan Configuration >> Job Configuration >> Task_
# Click on one of the task to view the details, and Internal Server Error will be returned

h4. Workaround
Set the locale to the following parameter. Please refer to the following [documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Bamboo+on+start-up] if you are not sure on how to set it.
{noformat}
-Duser.country=EN
-Duser.language=en
{noformat}
fields.summary: Internal Server error on task's detail when using Turkish locale

fields.description:
Hey.

We love the automatic branches detection in Bamboo. However, for some of our projects we don't use the default SVN ".../branches/" path but ".../releases/" instead. The problem is that this custom URL automagically resets itself back to default "/branches/" every time someone makes a change in plan configuration.

Steps to reproduce:

* Create a new plan.
* Create new Subversion source repository
* Go to "Branches" tab
* Click "Change Subversion branches URL" and change the URL from ".../branches/" to ".../releases/" (or something else). Save.
* Go to "Dependencies" tab. Add any child plan. Save
* Go back to "Branches" tab. See that the URL changed back to ".../branches/" again.

This does not seem to happen if you uncheck "Automatically detect root URL for branches" box in "Advanced Options" of SVN source repository settings and provide custom branches URL there.
fields.summary: Custom branch URL resets after every plan configuration change

fields.description:
We have discovered a vulnerability in WebWork 2, which is a part of the Struts web framework. 

In specific circumstances, attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that use these frameworks. 

In case of Bamboo, the attacker needs to be able to access Bamboo Web interface. A valid user account is not required to exploit this vulnerability.

Customers should be advised that this effects all previously released versions of Bamboo, except Bamboo OnDemand, Bamboo 4.4.8 (or newer) and Bamboo 4.3.5 (or newer). Bamboo 5.0 is not affected.

For more information on this issue, please see the security advisory [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=377520345]
fields.summary: Webwork 2 code injection vulnerability

fields.description: Some customers use Microsoft Lync Messenger, and would like to configure it in Bamboo in order to receive notifications.
fields.summary: Allow configuring Microsoft Lync Messenger in Bamboo

fields.description:
On Windows the detection of git from system.git.executable is failing to find git even if this is in PATH or in cygwin directory.

The detection algorithm mush be change so it would also look for PATH and for the default cygwin location C:\cygwin\bin\git.exe

Using Cygwin under Windows is a very common solution for cross-platform build systems.
fields.summary: system.git.executable fails to detect git in PATH or cygwin

fields.description:
Currently bamboo is running the inline scripts with bash on Unix and with cmd.exe on Windows and there is no way to change this behaviour.

This also means that you cannot write a single script that would be executed on all platforms.

Most of the other CI systems, including Jenkins, do allow this by simply using the shebang line in the script in order to choose what executable to use.

We discovered this design bug while evaluating Bamboo as an alternative to Jenkins. So far that's a real deal breaker.
fields.summary: Bamboo scripts cannot run cross-plaform because they ignore shebang line

User writes to me:

When a stage of build is re-ran it reports:

Build: #3723 is building - 42 mins remaining 
Rebuilt by Brian Freyling 

The 'rebuilt by name' is also wrong, it is listing who originally kicked off the build, not who triggered the rebuilding of a stage. (In this case Jacob).
fields.summary: rebuild is reporting negative time to complete

fields.description:
In the case multiple instances are capable of running a Job, the user has no way to configure which instance Bamboo starts by priority.

In the following example, this would be highly useful:
Instance A is a Large instance
Instance B is a Small instance

Job X can be run only on the large instance.
Job Y can be run on large and small instances.

If Job Y is in the queue alone, Bamboo needs to prefer to start instance B, but if instance A is already running then Y can be run there. 

However at the moment, there is no way to control this, while you can use custom Variable requirements you can only restrict the Job to run on a single instance.  You can't set it to run on both instance A and B, but prefer instance B.

Having prioritization of instances would help save money as to only start the smallest instance for certain jobs (if needed).
fields.summary: Allow for Prioritization of EC2 instances

fields.description: All local agents share the same Git cache. Implement a similar functionality for remote agents.
fields.summary: Allow multiple remote agents share the same Git cache

fields.description:
We were surprised to find out that few git and mercurial repositories failed to be imported due to SCM not being supported?!

We did not expect 100% import success but we expected at least the SCM configuration and script to run to be imported succesfully.
fields.summary: Support importing mercurial repositories from jenkins

fields.description:
Custom web repository viewers are available for subversion repositories. However, when the "Git" repository type is selected, they are not available. 

This is particularly a problem when using Bitbucket repositories with the Git repository type. Web repository links do appear when using the "Bitbucket" repository type, but the use of SSH keys is not supported, only username/password. However, using the Git repository type prevents a Bitbucket web repository from being specified :(

Ideally:
* Allow custom web repositories to be specified for Git repository types
* Allow the Bitbucket repository type to use SSH keys

or both :)
fields.summary: Git repository type doesn't allow generic web repository viewers

fields.description:
We should add shortcut links to:
* Agents
* Elastic Instances
** If disabled, 'Setup Elastic Bamboo'?
* Global Variables
* Shared Repositories
fields.summary: Improve administration shortcuts

fields.description: It only applies to [spot instances|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+Elastic+Bamboo#ConfiguringElasticBamboo-EC2spotinstances], but there's nothing in the documentation or the UI specifying this. It would be nice to make it clear!
fields.summary: Add an explanation of what "hourly rate" means for Elastic Instances

fields.description:
I recently setup some build plans at my company, and I like the branch management feature.

And I like the idea to automatically deploy to a development environment each night.
But I do not want all branch plans to be deploy, although I would like that to be optional (i.e. a manual stage).

This is how I've solved it now.
One plan with two stages and branch management enabled.
1) build/test and 
2) deploy (manual stage)

Another plan with identical two stages, but the 2nd stage (deploy) not manual.

This allows me a nightly deployment for 'master' (automatically), and I can optionally start deployment from a branch plan.

What I would like is that I could select a stage to be either
1) Automatic
2) Manual
3) Automatic for default branch/Manual for branch plan

This would achieve what I would like to do in a single plan, which would of course be far more easier to administer than having two sets of identical plans.
Not to mention the overhead that a single VCS revision is actually built twice.
fields.summary: As a plan admin, I would like to being able to configure a stage to be manual for branch plans only

fields.description: Is there a setting for enabling retrieving/viewing, copy/paste in the bamboo file browser? If not, this is a needed feature. It doesn't always make sense to have to commit to the repo to move things into the workspace. Thanks
fields.summary: Way to copy/paste, edit files in the workspace

fields.description:
Weekly tasks like wiping the local maven repository or update the agent's binary capabilities we still have to do manually or provisioned. Therefor we need the agents to be disabled or even shut down. 

While wiping the GIT cache I just saw 

{code}Scheduling deletion of selected Git Caches on agents: linux_agent21_1 (2), linux_agent21_2 (2), linux_agent21_3 (2), linux_agent21_4 (2), linux_agent21_5 (2) (....){code}

It would be very nice if we could schedule custom tasks for all agents across a big agent farm and even better if these could be normal bamboo tasks (e.g. ant/maven execution)
fields.summary: Being able to schedule custom tasks for all agents

fields.description:
There are potential reasons why a plugin may not want itself to be visible in the task selector e.g. licensing.

We should provide a conditional to decide whether to show it (maybe the same as we do for web items/panels.)
fields.summary: Ability to not show a task in the task selector
Pattern Match Labelling not working...

fields.description:
When specifying the time in a "Single Daily Build" or cron-based build trigger, it's unclear what timezone this is in. This is a problem when, for example, your bamboo server is in one timezone, your build agents are in another timezone, and your workstation in yet another.

At the very least, the UI should tell the user which timezone will be applied, but better yet the UI should allow the user to specify the timezone explicitly, to avoid ambiguity and to make it clear in the plan config that a given build is to run at e.g. 7pm Sydney time, regardless of where the various components of the build system are sitting.
fields.summary: Allow timezone to be specified for Single Daily Build or Cron triggers

fields.description:

/Users/eboudrant/Library/Developer/Xcode/DerivedData/TheApp-asymdhptubvzwrgkusurugyjwigo/Build/Products/Release-iphoneos/TheApp.app

The plugin expect a OS Application Path relative to the working directory. It seems it not possible to build an IPA when we are using a workspace.

fields.description:
Configure Bamboo to use elastic agents with the following settings for the instance mamangement:
{code}
    Bamboo will shut down elastic instances which have been idle for more than 10 minutes.
    A maximum of 1 elastic instance can be started each minute.
    New elastic instances will be started when all of the following conditions have been met:
        There is at least 1 build in a queue.
        There is at least 1 build in a queue that are executable on elastic images.
        The average time builds have been waiting in a queue is at least 1 minute.
        The number of elastic instances on your AWS account that are not controlled by Bamboo does not exceed 100.
{code}
With the above settings, it will be expected that Bamboo will spun only an instance of the agent for every build. This is however the opposite where Bamboo starts 2 instances. This comes with additional cost as two instances are started to service the build. The following can be seen in the instances startup:

Now if we enable DEBUG level on the class *com.amazonaws* more information are provided. I am attaching a section of the logs. 

*workaround*

The workaround is to set "The average time builds have been waiting in a queue" to something unreasonable big, like for example 28,500 minutes (or even more).

The reason we should do that is that the Bamboo EC2 optimizer (the mechanism in Bamboo that can spin on or shut down EC2 instances according to the build queue load) algorithm works as follows (with details excluded):
1) each minute run a check if there is a necessity to spin (or shut down) an EC2 instance:
1.1) (more-less) if there are builds in the queue that can't be built with the current agents at all, start the relevant EC2 images
1.2) if there are builds in the queue that can be built by EC2 agent and Bamboo is not spinning up EC2 images:
1.2.1) check the thresholds (time line the queue, total builds in the queue, etc), and if we cross the thresholds - spin the relevant EC2 images

And that "EC2 Optimizer" is running this algorithm each 60 seconds.
Now, the problem is when the newly EC2 image is spun up and register itself as a ready agent. Before that new agent will pickup the build some time will pass or elapse (communication, initializing, etc). So the build that triggered EC2 image startup will still stay in the queue, most probably it will stay in the queue for the succeeding "EC2 Optimizer" run. And that succeeding run will check in the step (1.2) that Bamboo is not spinning EC2 images (because EC2 agent just transitioned to a ready state) so it will check the thresholds (did build stay 1 minute in queue? for sure - EC2 agents spin up in more than 1 minute) and as a result - the second EC2 image will be started by Bamboo again.

This seemed to have fixed itself in 4.4.5
fields.summary: Automatic elastic instance management spun off multiple instances for every build

fields.description:
Having two stages in Bamboo, with one job for each stage, when the first stage gets triggered from the repository, it shows the correct user for building/updating that stage under Current Activity -> Recently Built. But for the second stage, the user shows up as anonymous while it's the same user as the one who has triggered the first stage.

*The second stage is a serial stage and starts right after the first stage.

Below is what's happening in Bamboo and the reason for this behavior:
1) when a build of a plan is triggered, it:
1.1) stores the trigger reason against the build (whether it was manually triggered, or whether triggered by changes in the repository).
1.2) all repositories are pulled for any changes since last build, even those not-triggering the build from the 2nd stage, and these changes are stored against the build.
2) when the job finishes (note that our case build consist of two JOBS) it is stored in the build/job result only the commits/changes that are relevant to that job. So in our example, the first stage job will contain changes from perforce1 (if there were any, but since it was triggered by the changes, then certainly there were some changes), and the second stage job will contain changes from perforce2 (so most probably: no changes at all).
3) the "Recently Built" activity stream scans for the recently finished jobs, and uses the following logic to determine what to display:
if it is a build that was manually triggered - displays the username stored against trigger reason (note that this data is stored differently than the changes from repositories - it is stored together with the trigger reason mentioned in 1.1). 
If it is a build triggered by "code changed" event, then we display username(s) of people that are recorded as authors of the commits relevant to that job.
Given that we don't store irrelevant code changes in the job build result, and given that usually there is no commits on the perforce2 repository (the one used in second stage), so the "Recently Built" is displaying "Anonymous" user as it doesn't see any authors.
fields.summary: "Anonymous" user under "Recently Built" for plans with two stages

fields.description:
This feature will allow skipping any Stage of a Plan during execution Based on a condition. For example, when configuring a skip condition on a Stage, users can have something like these:  "If the branch name is 'test_branch', skip this Stage", "If it's 9am to 6pm now, skip this Stage", "If the Plan is triggered manually, skip this Task".

Skip this Stage based on:
# time interval
# how the Plan (and therefore the Stage) has been triggered
# who triggered the Plan/Stage (list of user names or groups)
# who committed changes to the Configured Repositories for this Plan(Stage)
# what branch is running the Stage (the user can specify a list of branch names, or set a regular expression)
# the Agent or Environment (user can specify the agent name)

(This list can be expanded)
fields.summary: Add skip conditions to control the flow of Bamboo Stage execution

fields.description:
When a plan uses a Git Repository that uses Git Submodules and that plan also has branches with Branch Merging enabled, it will never run the branch plan as Bamboo fails to check out the Submodule. It will remain stuck on 'Queued' for about 10 minutes, then fail, never reaching the Elastic Agent.

Disabling Branch Merging will allow the branch plan to run successfully,  this also shows that the elastic agent successfully checks out the Submodule (once an SSH key is [present on the agent|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-11369]).

The Bamboo log itself shows the following error

fields.description:
It would be very handy and solve many issues for us if we could get the new "Artifact Downloader" task to get other than latest successful Artifact from a job.

I suggest following options :

- Latest
- Specific build
- Regex to match labels to a specific build

+Background+
The reason for needing this is that we have dependencies on other plans that produce a module or a whole piece of software (software A) and let's say they did a release of Software A and they save the build in Bamboo by labeling it then we would like to use that Artifact from the build as input for another plan (Software B) that depends on it on each build until next time Software A releases a new build that's worth start using. This would solve so many issues we have today with Jenkins and CruiseControl where dependencies are handled manually by copied to network drives.
fields.summary: Get specific build artifact with Artifact Downloader task

fields.description:
Bamboo tries to predict how long a job has left to execute. This is quite helpful. However, the calculation could be more accurate if it also considered environmental factors such as:

* Which agent is executing the job (since different agents might be running on wildly different hardware)
* Is the agent starting with a clean workspace.
fields.summary: Expected job execution time could consider environmental factors

fields.description:
I have been trying out the 5.0 beta and have been playing around with Artifact Downloader Task feature.
I have set up a job in beta1 that copies the artifacts from another plan and tests it. However the job stopped working when I upgraded to beta2 (and beta3).
Here's my setup:
Plan 1:
Has 1 job that checks out the code and builds a set of .deb packages
In the artifacts tab for the job has the artifact collection set up - '*.deb' pattern and 'Shared' checked
Plan 2:
Has Plan 1 as parent
Has 1 job with only 1 task - 'Artifact Downloader Task' that points to Plan 1 as 'Source Plan' and 'All artifacts' as 'Artifact Name' (tested it with pointing to exact artifacts in 'Artifact Name' as well)
Plan 1 succedes and gathers the artifacts just fine - I can download them from the plan page.
Plan 2 fails with the following message:

fields.description:
h4.Problem Description
If Bamboo has branch name with JIRA issue key included in its name, as long as there's an Application Link between Bamboo and JIRA, the link between the Bamboo plan and JIRA Issue will be established automatically.

However if for Automatic branch detection in Bamboo, it won't create the link straightaway in JIRA. Instead, it will just create the Link in Bamboo to JIRA but not from JIRA to Bamboo. It will show a button like the following screenshot.
!bamboojirabranchlink.png!

The following warning message will be generated in Bamboo log.
{noformat}
2013-06-13 18:35:42,270 WARN [1-BranchJiraLinkingBackgroundThread:pool-4-thread-2] [JiraBranchLinkingServiceImpl] Could not create remote issue link from issue 'TEST-3' to plan branch 'TEST project - Plan Github - TEST-3'. No matching JIRA project could be found on any linked JIRA Server.
{noformat}

Most probably Bamboo is looking for similar Project name in JIRA. Nevertheless, this behaviour didn't happen when the Branch is created manually, or added manually from the detected branch from *Create Branch* button.

h4.How it should work
It should create a link automatically from JIRA. Just like when it's added manually from *Create Branch* button. Just like the following screenshot.
!bamboojirabranchlink2.png!

This is replicated on JIRA 6.0.2

h4.Steps to replicate the issue
# Establish an Application Link between JIRA and Bamboo.
# Make sure the Application Link works fine. You could achieve this by commenting JIRA Issue key on Bamboo Build and see if it will be linked to JIRA.
# Create a test repository and a branch and name the branch with JIRA Issue Key.
# On Plan Configuration, choose Branches and make sure *Automatically manage branches* is checked.
# Wait and see until the branch is added.
# On Bamboo Plan switch to the branch which the name is similar with JIRA Issue Key.

h4. Workaround
Create a user {{SYSTEM}} in Jira internal directory.
fields.summary: Automatic branch detection is unable to create link to JIRA automatically

fields.description:
I would like to be able to have a UI to customize the name, location and contents of the build-stamper plugin.

Currently with a Maven build I have to configure each project individually and add command -D variables to every build. Which looks horrible and is difficult across multiple builds.  I'd like to be able to configure the plugin to tell it what and how to create the build-number file. Additionally it would be nice if the location and the name of the file would be configurable, say naming it build.properties and putting it in my maven target/classes directory.

I might try this my self as I see the code is out there as a sample
fields.summary: Make the build stamper configurable

fields.description:
Here is an excerpt from Bamboo's REST API documentation. It describes the URL you would hit in order to see things about a build result, such as logEntries.

https://docs.atlassian.com/bamboo/REST/5.0-SNAPSHOT/#d2e428

The _*emphasis*_ is mine.

{panel}
h2. /result/\{projectKey}\-_*\{buildKey}*_-\{buildNumber : (\[0-9]+)\|(latest)}?expand&favourite&start-index&max-results

h3. resource-wide template parameters
||parameter || value || description ||
| buildNumber | string | buildNumber (numeric value or 'latest') |
| buildKey | string | _*plan key*_ (_*might be*_ simply planKey or _*composite planKey-jobKey*_) | 
| projectKey | string | project key |

h3. Methods
h4. GET
Provide build result specified by projectKey-buildKey-buildNumber. Build number may be specified also as "latest" for latest result.

h5. request query parameters

|| parameter || value || description ||
| expand | string | expands build result details on request. Possible values are: changes, metadata, artifacts, comments, labels, jiraIssues, stages, logEntries. stages expand is available only for top level plans. It allows to drill down to job results using stages.stage.results.result. _*logEntries and testResults are available only for job results*_ |
| favourite | boolean | filters build results list to show only results for favourite plans. Works only for authenticated user |
| start-index | int | start index for results list (zero based) |
| max-results | int | maximum size for returned list |

h5. available response representations:

* 404 \[expand]
* 200 - application/xml, application/json (resultDetails) \[expand]
* 401 \[expand]
{panel}

The problem here is that the most vital information is obfuscated behind some opaque terms. If you want to get {{logEntries}} from bamboo, you need to know that logEntries are only available for jobs. You then need to know how to provide a job in the query string. Presently, you would have to be forgiven for not knowing or realising that a buildKey actually can contain a jobKey.

Please consider rewriting the documentation such that the places a jobKey can appear are much more obvious.

Please also consider splitting the documentation up a little to distinguish the URLs where specific data is available. For instance, the above section should really be two sections: one for the non-job-specific information (which would exclude logEntries etc.) and then another section for the URL with a job in it, which would talk about the job-specific information available.
fields.summary: Bamboo REST documentation needs clarity when describing buildKey, planKey and/or jobKey
